children.subject: This is so on point! Although I don't think anyone has an idea how to tackle all these extremely valid points made by the OP :(

You touch on some very strong points I have been dealing myself. In addition there those who “have” and those who “have not” meaning there some students have a safe and distract free place to stay where others don’t. Some students have families that have the financial resources to be out of work for several months while others don’t. Most of my family is out of work. Unfortunately they fall in that class of low skill labor and helping them fill out unemployment forms is stressful. Debts are piling up. Everyone has unique situations but at this point several students are struggling to put school as top priority.
Thank you so much for speaking out for voices, like mine. I support this post and urge the EECS department/community to find ways to incorporate this thought into the rest of the semester.

Thank you for posting this. Although I am fortunate enough to have a home in the Bay Area, I have been living separate from my parents with just my sibling for the past month due to flight cancellations from the pandemic. All my family members have lost their jobs and we have no health insurance, and I live in constant fear that my family members or I can contract the virus with no guarantee of surviving either the physical toll or financial strain it will cause. 

In the past few weeks, studying for midterms has honestly been the last thing on my mind as as I’ve had to deal with moving out all of my belongings alone from my dorm and having to fend for my siblings and I by taking care of ourselves and waiting up to an hour just to get some groceries. 

It’s been a difficult time for everyone during this time even if some of us are fortunate enough to live in California, and everyone’s circumstances are different and should not be taken any lighter than others. 

Thank you for opening up this discussion and I hope everyone stays healthy and pushes through this difficult tome. <3

Mandatory P/NP is one important step to help resolve the inequities that have come up as a result of this situation. I've heard the university isn't even considering it right now which is pretty ridiculous.

This was so beautifully said--and the OP did an amazing job of considering everyone's viewpoints. We definitely should be more respectful to our course staffs and professors because they are really in the same boat as us. They too have never dealt with this before, and our TAs are also students like us, dealing with their own academic pressures. With that said, I agree with the commenter above me--it is kind of sad that Berkeley would care more about its own legal standing than its own students...and I am saying that as someone who has worked really hard this semester too. Mandatory P/NP is needed to end the constant confusion, uncertainty, fear, and anxiety. I think they really need to understand that as the OP said, just issuing a small change to our policy doesn't make a difference. We need some sort of guarantee that we will not be penalized in the future for our decisions right now. While several programs across the country have said that they will accept P/NP grades if they are made mandatory by our university, no one is clearly stating what will be done if our university has only made it optional, and we still take the P/NP. We still have three or so more weeks left--Berkeley can still right this wrong.

history.content:
I want to post this here because I don’t think there’s enough discussion from students about the situation that we’re all going through right now. I honestly think that hearing from each other is one of the most important things we can do right now – and I hope that sharing these concerns raises awareness to bring some positive change in our community.

 

It’s week two of our mandatory shelter-in-place order here in California. For the average student, we’re just “working from home” – so our normal problem sets, midterms, projects, and exams should continue to be assigned & graded normally, correct?

 

Let me put this in perspective.

 

We’re at home, stripped from our critical support system of the friends & communities that we've grown reliant upon over the years.

 

We’re dealing with tensions within our own families— tensions that can cause conflict & struggle escalated by being within feet of each other 24/7.

 

We’re dealing with situations where our parents are being forced into positions of financial instability (10 million Americans filed for unemployment in the past few weeks).

 

We’re dealing with the emotional pain of seeing those close to us sacrifice their personal safety to fight for others – fighting by showing up to work as nurses, doctors, grocery store employees, or delivery workers.

 

We're dealing with being forced to step up & support both our younger siblings and our senior citizens at a level we've never had to before. 

 

We’re dealing with a reality where those closest to us are either working to fight the virus, or trying to fight the virus because they’ve contracted it. 

 

And the most important thing of all: the students who’re most impacted by this don’t have the time to share their stories. They don’t have the time to read Piazza, to sign up for courses, to study for exams. They’re fighting the fight of their lives, and we’re here trying to figure out how to administer fair exams.

 

To the EECS department, and to my fellow students, I say this. 

 

Waving a magic wand over the grading system this semester doesn’t change anything — nothing changes when we continue to receive our weekly 10-hour problem sets. Nothing changes when we learn about one, two, three class final projects due within a span of a few weeks. Nothing changes when we open up our emails to learn about the 40% average score on a midterm. Nothing changes when we endlessly debate guidelines on how to effectively remote proctor exams, how to structure tests to discourage cheating, how to adjust grade bins, and how to deal with the curve. 

 

Nothing changes. 

 

So how do we, as students, enact meaningful change?

First, we need to accept the fact that a growing number of our peers are struggling right now. School is secondary right now for a non-trivial amount of American college students, and we need to accept the fact that this will become the new reality for an increasing number of our peers. 

 

We need to work together to respect those in the EECS community who’re facing mental or physical struggles due to these new circumstances. We need to think twice before firing off those 10+ clarification posts seconds after midterm grades are released; we need to hold off on questions about grade bins, curves, and final distributions (or ask them in a private manner that doesn't inflict stress on our classmates because they might have a 1000 other things they are dealing with that are more important than exam grades); we need to acknowledge the fact that just as we are, course staff is working incredibly hard to adjust in times like these.

 

We need to provide strong social support systems to each other, and to our communities. We need to support those around us that are struggling, even if they don't show it. More of our families are struggling than we realize – whether that’s financial, emotional, or personal. We need to support those in our immediate communities that need our help, in whatever form that may take.

 

Now more than ever, we need to come together as one community of computer scientists and electrical engineers. We owe it to those members of our community who’re unable to share their stories.

 

As for a few comments department-wide:

This far into this crisis, we should accept the fact that simply tweaking our normal workflow to adapt to distant learning doesn't work. As an example, making exams more difficult, more time intensive, or both doesn't lead to a fair assessment of one’s command of the material. Getting back a score of 25%, only to be told that “it’s OK - you classmates did just as bad” – isn’t, by any means, good for a student’s mental health. A fair exam is not one that takes well over 150-200% of the time allocated to complete start to finish because its length will “discourage cheating.” Some classes have moved towards releasing exams in a week-long format, where students have a chance to work together with others and write up well thought-out solutions to each question; this approach strengthens our community, where students work with each other, not against each other – while also ensuring that we’re in command of the material. Let’s see more of this emphasis on collaborative learning and face-to-face group work – it’s one of the most important things we need right now.

 

Debating the campus-wide ban on remote proctoring exacerbates the problems that we face as a community. Hearing conflicting stories from the UC Berkeley Administration, College of Engineering, EECS Department, and our own professors only adds to the confusion. What’s the result? Intense competition among peers, stress over distributions, fear over academic dishonesty, and a general distraction from learning the material at hand. We need to acknowledge the fact that our TA’s, and GSI’s are also going through incredible amounts of stress right now. Rather than asking our GSI’s to spend countless hours designing a bullet-proof exam, we need to be asking them to focus on working one-on-one with students over virtual office hours or discussion – perhaps even reaching out to students who aren’t comfortable reaching out themselves. 

 

It’s a catastrophic miscalculation to assume that providing a “life as normal” mentality benefits the average student by giving them something to focus on during the situation at hand. We cannot bear the workload spanned by normal projects, assignments, and problem sets when we should be supporting those close to us in times of need. It’s ludicrous to expect students to accomplish what we were capable of accomplishing in the classroom four weeks ago – we are mentally in a much, much different spot now. It’s good to maintain some sort of normality in our lives – but that has to be balanced with a non-trivial reduction in pace and/or material. The rigor and intensity of a Berkeley education does not come from overloading students with assignments. Even top students might be finding their current situation unmanageable, so restructuring and reworking these assignments to they teach and emphasize the same content but are more manageable maintains the educational quality that Berkeley is renowned for.

 

A PNP policy doesn’t magically make all these stressors disappear. If anything, it adds an additional weight for students to contend with in this game of exams, transcripts, GPA’s, internships, graduate school, and research that we are trained to play. Even though PNP theoretically enables students to take some pressure off of themselves, the reality is that many of us are not. There are more than a few people with the mentality of “I think all of my peers will take a letter grade => I need to take a letter grade.” This is why there remain questions about how classes will be curved on course Piazzas and why students are reacting the same way to grades that they always do: with stress and apprehension about the future. There is also a fair amount of conflict over whether or not a letter grade in a class will be advantageous for research and graduate school. Even though Berkeley graduate programs have said they will look at this semester with special consideration, it says nothing about other graduate programs across the nation. Moreover, with many students taking classes in fields which they want to specialize in, it is hard to believe that would not impact research positions down the line because many of them have grade thresholds for particular classes.

 

The PNP policy is a good first step, but I think the following items would be helpful to ensure it has the impact that it’s intended to have.

  1. An open channel for feedback as the situation evolves. A select number of courses have been checking in via surveys to discern important information about time zones, focus levels, etc. I think a department-wide survey would be beneficial to all involved; as students, knowing that our perspectives are being taken into account when making policy decisions would be beneficial to all.

  2. A uniform statement from EECS & L&S CS about how to choose PNP vs. Letter Grade. There’s been lots of information coming from various components: faculty, peers, the university, etc. Some clarity and uniformity would provide support to all of us in this time of need.

  3. Transparency about how the EECS department is working with other universities to ensure that we’re working at a level that’s balanced with other universities. Now that we’re at home interacting with students studying across the world, it’s imperative that policy enacted here stays consistent & fair with what’s occurring across the country – and if it doesn’t, to understand how and why we’re different. 

 

Let’s step up and meet this moment together!
history.subject: An open letter to our community
